What would say is your longer-term target? Is that sort of a number that we should be expecting, or do you think it will be down to a lower level of leverage as we have seen historically? And the second question regarding the committed funding that you have in place. I am not sure how much detail you can give but perhaps even more important than the pricing of that debt. What is the actual maturity of that debt, and trying to gauge at what point would you have to come back to the market given the current volatility you have?

So on the capital structure after the transaction, it will 2.7 times, that is in our view quite aggressive knowing the conservative stance of the company. So going forward, we will go back to a certain extent, but certainly not sustainable to levels where we have been in the last two years. It's a bit similar story we had after the BBAG acquisition, where we took on for the first time substantial debt. We said that is bringing out as a little bit further than where we would like to be, so we pay that down, but that will be a fluctuation over time. So it is certainly not as conservative as we have been in the last two years, but it will certainly also not stay at the level which we will style off after the transaction.

Yes, finances, fully committed are two tranches. One tranche of one year of 1.1 billion sterling, and that tranche will be refinanced in capital markets. We have the option to prolong that with another year, so it is in principal one year but we can extend that to two years. And the other part's 2.85 billion sterling is on a five year timeframe but that is a bank loan which will stay a bank loan. Next two debts, that depends a little bit how much we want and have to refinance of the existing debt in Scottish & Newcastle. We have of course our revolving credit facility available of €2 billion.

Hi. It's Jon Fell from Deutsche Bank. A couple of questions. First of all, on input costs again, given what we are seeing with inflation at the moment, how much of it is – how much of a concern is it for you to go and try and fix supply and price as much as you can for 2009, right now? And how much of a risk is there that we would see another big increase in cost perhaps related to 2009? And then the second question is on tax, Scottish & Newcastle yesterday were seeing very confident that the 20% tax rate they have is sustainable going forward, and is there any reason why it wouldn't be sensible for us to build in a blend of their rate and yours, going forward, or other reasons why it could be higher or lower than that?

On the raw materials, and packaging materials typically, you have a range of things where you can do multi-year contracts, I will cite hops for instance has a multi-year contract. If you go to the serial markets that starts to be much more volatile and much more complicated they go from harvest to harvest. And a good harvest and a bad harvest that can mean a yield from half to double. So, it's very difficult to ask for – at the end of the day, you have a farmer and he has to commit for a price, and some do it, but not all. So, you can not ask for let's say hedging that kind of risks in this market. And beer brewing barley is a specific type of barley, and that is again a very small part of the total barley market. It typically represents 10 to 15% of the global barley markets. And it's more – there is no liquid market for that. There are no forward contracts with all the options you have for wheat or what have you. So it is not so easy to fix that down, because you have two different angles. On the one hand, you have the structural pressure on the demand, which comes from Asia for feed barley and cereals in absolute, you all know that, and the second thing is demand for biofuels with the first generation biofuel and the second generation biofuel, but that plays – that gives us structural pressure on the demand on the commodities that we use. And that is there for stay, and then you have the second element, the harvest, and you know that consecutive draughts in Australia have been kind of are taking a toll on these kind of markets, and that is very difficult to hedge.

Now when you come to the supplies of let's say aluminum, in the old times we were kind of making a contract with an aluminum can manufacturer. Now you have to buy yourself the aluminum, which you need and you have to bear that risk, because there is no can manufacturer who will take that risk anymore in the world. So, we have to play on the metal exchange to have this comfort. So there also on the positive side you have more amplitude to hedge yourselves going into the future in that kind. The glass market is yet another game, that's a market where capacity is very determining of what prices are. To make glass, you need an oven, and an oven is flowing glass seven years consecutively day and night without interruption. So those are very the most inflexible plants in the world, it's even more inflexible than a steel mill, and that makes that – the capacity supply is really determining what the price offer would be, and for 35% is the price of the energy, which then again is difficult kind of fixing well into 2009. If you ask me a number of these things, we fixed already for 2009, but also a number of our supply we can not fix into 2008. So, it's difficult to give clarity on that.

And on the tax rates, and the lower tax rates of Scottish and Newcastle of 20%. It's very much related to the way how they deal with France, and there is a double dip in the interest deduction between France and UK, and clearly by the break-up of the company that will be lost. So, you can not just take their tax rate and ours, and start making a blend. Your have to go back to the individual tax rate of the individual countries.
All right.
I hope you will free us up from these chairs and we go for a beer.
Thank you very much.
